title: Wednesday, 7th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Why's it only Wednesday? Bloody hell.

BE11:04am

Let me try poking around to see if this damn jalopy of a website can actually work for once.

BE11:04am

(╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻

11:04 am
BE11:05am

Ah! There. That seemed to work.

BE11:05am

Okay, let's start again. If you don't have a functioning comment box try refreshing the page.

BE11:05am

Or just don't comment. Your choice. I'm fine with either of those.

11:05 am
undefined
BE11:05am

Welcome, then, to Markets Live.

BE11:06am

Here, have a picture.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

That's Benvenuto di Giovanni's Madonna della Misericordia (1481)

BE11:06am

The fresco in the lobby of Monte dei Paschi di Siena.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Commissioned eight years after MPS started out ...

BE11:06am

... as a charity to combat loan sharks.

BE11:07am

We go on a lot about MPS being the world's oldest surviving bank, but it only converted into a proper bank in the mid 17th century.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

And even then, the definition of "proper bank" has changed a bit.

BE11:07am

For example, it gave half its profits to destitute nuns and the other half to street urchins.

BE11:08am

Were that still the case, the nuns and street orphans would be on the hook for a ~€5bn loss this year.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Instead, it's the EU that's going to carry the can.

BE11:08am

Maybe.

BE11:08am

https://www.ft.com...-9e3b-54ac49a02a7f

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Italian banks stocks are leaping this morning on the back of media reports Rome could make an EU state aid request worth €15bn to help prop up its financial system.

Shares in Intesa Sanpaolo, Unicredit and Banco Popolare jumped more than 3 per cent at the start of trading this morning, with the wider Italian bank index climbing 3.5 per cent.

BE11:08am

A report in the daily La Stampa this morning said Rome was ready to make a request to the eurozone’s bailout fund – the European Stability Mechanism – to inject funds into its most troubled lender, Monte dei Paschi and a host of its smaller banks.

Shares in MPS soared more 10 per cent on the speculation. Investors have been awaiting the outcome of a €5bn private sector recapitalisation plan for the world’s oldest bank which has been thrown into jeopardy following a ‘No’ vote in Sunday’s referendum and the impending resignation of prime minister Matteo Renzi.

BE11:09am

Great!

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The Italian treasury denied the bailout reports on Wednesday. “No request to the ESM is being prepared” said a spokesman.

BE11:09am

Oh.

BE11:09am

That all moves us on a fraction from yesterday, when the idea was that the Italian Treasury might buy out retail bond holders.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

So they didn't have to wear the loss of a government-led recapitalisation.

BE11:10am

Quick bit of Goldman to summarise this mess.

BE11:10am

With €1 bn secured from the debt-to-equity swap concluded on December 2, BMPS needs to raise another €4 bn to finance the losses related to the planned €9 bn NPL disposal. To avoid public fund injections, BMPS recapitalization and NPL disposals require substantial foreign private capital commitment. The “No” vote of December 4 alters, at the very least, the terms at which this capital would be provided: anchor investors have already delayed their final decision by 3-4 days (Reuters, December 5, 2016)

11:10 am
BE11:10am

In case of failure of the private recapitalization plans, BMPS management stated on an investor call held on November 30 that public capital injection may be required, and that burden sharing may apply to junior note holders. On our estimates, there is €2 bn issued to retail holders. While the generous ECB backstops for bank liquidity remain firmly in place, the imposition of losses on this part of the capital structure could carry contagion risk to other Italian banks’ deposit flows and pricing, and impact investor confidence.

BE11:10am

Implications
BMPS faces a year-end deadline for its recapitalization, and the lack of appetite of private investors so far to complete it, has been an overhang on the sector for several months. Therefore, if implemented, a solution to BMPS issues which would not affect the retail funding market, and would also avoid extensive contribution by other local banks, would be a seen as positively by the markets, in our view.

BE11:12am

(@vlade: well indeed: nearly nothing + 3% is still nearly nothing. Though of all the journalistic conceits we're guilty of, things soaring is probably the most benign.)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

So! European banks rally across the board.

Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 218.00, up 8.9 (+4.26%), High: 218.20, Low: 208.70, Volume: 10.85m
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 682.80, up 25.8 (+3.93%), High: 688.50, Low: 664.90, Volume: 3.50m
11:12 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 234.35, up 7.6 (+3.35%), High: 235.55, Low: 228.85, Volume: 20.94m
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 674.10, up 20.1 (+3.07%), High: 674.80, Low: 663.50, Volume: 13.17m
BE11:14am

(HSBC graph over the past few months is extraordinary, incidentally. That's on bond yields and pressure coming off NIM rather than anything company specific, of course, but it's still a hell of a move for what I think is the FTSE's #2 stock by weight.)

11:15 am
BE11:15am

There was a pretty good one of those UBS Evidence Lab things a day or two ago .....

BE11:15am

....... which I'll quote, in spite of it being stale, because I don't think I quoted it earlier.

BE11:15am

Many global financials investors have enjoyed the recent strong performance of the US banks, fuelled by hopes for Trump-driven de-regulation and rising probability of higher Fed Funds rates. With market-implied inflation expectations climbing sharply in the UK and Europe some are asking whether the reflation trade might bear fruit here too. Banks in both regions are lagging relative to the increase in inflation expectations.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Our house view is that the Bank of England and ECB will look the other way as FX-driven inflation comes through in 2017, holding rates flat to the end of 2018 at least. With tepid growth forecasts we don't disagree, but given the political environment and with key elections due in the Netherlands, France and Germany next year it is worth acknowledging the risk that bank stability issues in Germany and poor returns to savers across Europe could drive an earlier normalisation of bank rates. We would expect this to drive a material re-rating of German and southern European banks in particular.

BE11:17am

Plus, a pretty amazing chart.

BE11:17am

11:18 am
undefined
BE11:18am

But enough of banks.

BE11:19am

FTSE ahead 1.5%, 102 points, at 6881

11:19 am
BE11:19am

...... and fallers more interesting than risers.

WPP PLC (WPP:LSE): Last: 1,656, down 38 (-2.24%), High: 1,690, Low: 1,643, Volume: 1.73m
BE11:20am

WSJ story overnight about alleged shady practices in advertising

11:20 am
BE11:20am

(Shocked, shocked to find ... etc.)

BE11:21am

http://www.wsj.com...ndustry-1481046420

BE11:21am

Okay, so it seems that ad agencies only pitch clients a concept.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

"You've got a price comparison site to sell? How about a meerkat puppet with a fake Russian accent and an annoying catchphrase." That kind of thing.

BE11:22am

But then the actual making of your ad goes out to tender.

BE11:23am

The filming of said meerkat can be done in house, or it can be done by a third party.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

WSJ reports that agencies allegedly asked third party firms to submit inflated "check bids" to justify moving the business to an in-house agency.

BE11:24am

Brokers are stuck between saying, "interesting!" and "we knew already though," and "not terribly relevant to the figures".

BE11:25am

Barclays incoming.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

While this investigation commenced before the publication of the ANA report, Rebecca Meiklejohn, the anti-trust attorney on the case, contacted the ANA to get further details into the alleged production bid-rigging. Although the final draft of the ANA report does not include any reference to bid-rigging, an earlier version of the report outlined cases of it. Rebecca Meiklejohn has since spoken to K2 Intelligence (one of the parties hired by ANA) who have provided evidence from their probe. According to documents seen by the WSJ, the initial draft of the ANA report claimed that “six producers and editors from independent production firms reported being asked to submit so-called check bids on projects that agencies had already determined were going to their in-house outfits. The post-production companies were urged to inflate their bid to create a paper trail that justified to the advertiser its decision to award the project to an in-house facility, which provided a rival bid at a lower price.”

BE11:25am

This is unlikely to represent a significant amount of revenues for the holding companies. The WSJ article estimates that the US production market is worth around US$5bn. According to AdAge, the top 4 agencies (Omnicom, WPP, Publicis, and Interpublic) generate over US$25bn of revenues in the US. So given that only a portion of the US$5bn production market will go towards agencies, the financial impact is unlikely to be material.

BE11:26am

That said, in the face of growing criticism of agency business practices and conduct, the news of the DoJ investigation provides another cause for concern. Despite the relatively low risk to the financials, such practices, if proven, could potentially have a disproportionately large negative impact on investor sentiment. So far, none of the agency holding companies have made an official comment. We spoke to WPP and Omnicom and both are saying they were not aware of the DoJ contacting any of their employees. Both companies also confirmed that production is a very small part of their revenues.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

(@Mouselet: I'm reminded that Tim Hayward, the FT's food person, used to be big in advertising. If you meet him at one of our corporate events, do put that question to him. His past-life stories are fantastic and lurid.)

BE11:27am

On the positive side, the DoJ probe does not involve client budget mishandling and is relatively contained from a financial point of view. However, if proven, these allegations are likely to damage investor’s confidence in the peer group and support the bears’ view that these large complex organizations are still prone to conduct issues. It is also unclear if this is just a US problem or has an international reach. The investigation is still in progress and it is not clear who the players involved are but, looking at history, agencies (as all other large and complex companies) have been susceptible to conduct issues in the past. As damaging as this might have been at the time, the industry has been able to recover and continue to make strides towards better management and conduct, while maintaining a strong financial track record. Transparency is already high on everyone’s agenda and we point to the multitude of client audits initiated post the ANA report that have so far found no wrongdoing.

BE11:27am

On the DoJ news both Omnicom and Interpublic were down around 5% but subsequently recovered to close down 2% and down 3%, respectively. We have Overweight ratings on Havas, Publicis, and WPP with price targets of €8.50, €76.00, and 2,100p, respectively. We rate Omnicom Equal Weight with a US$87.00 price target.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And Citi.

BE11:28am

This is an interesting and important topic and unfortunately the allegations of wrongdoing on behalf of the agencies - frankly whether they are substantiated or not - will be yet another factor that undermines the relationship between agencies in general and advertisers. This is, however, neither a new issue nor indeed is it a particularly surprising one.

BE11:28am

Starting with its relative newness. Clearly the new news here is the initiation of a DoJ investigation but the debate over whether agencies are, in effect, 'double dipping' has raged for almost as long as we have been looking at the agencies and certainly the last 15-20 years. Indeed as the WSJ article notes, the investigation that has been announced echoes a similar investigation in 2002.

Second, we should consider whether it is a surprise. Here we should be careful. If there are proven cases of absolute wrongdoing, then clearly that is unsanctionable. This said, it is important to note that the phenomenon of 'double dipping' or 'layering' is unfortunately a direct natural consequence of the change in revenue model that the ad agency industry has seen over the last 20-30 years. Why is this?

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Under a standard commission model, the price charged by agencies - typically 15% of total media spend - was non-negotiable and was meant to cover all the costs associated with delivering a media advertising campaign. Under a fee based system the model largely moved to 'cost plus', i.e. the agency presented the advertiser with a list of the basic expenses and then charged a supplemental margin on top.

Once this new mode of remuneration was initiated it became an obvious source of incremental return for the agencies to get exposure to the sub-components of the bill. Tenders for production work would have involved third parties who also might work on a 'cost-plus-margin' basis and therefore disintermediation of these groups simply made sense.

Now the specific allegation is not that this is an illegitimate way to make money but rather that the agencies weren't either (a) transparent on what they were doing (questions over beneficial ownership) or (b) sufficiently rigorous in their tender process for more basic functions.

BE11:28am

(Yes, there's a lot of this.)

BE11:29am

In this context it is worth noting that many large and sophisticated advertisers - a list that includes P&G - will have long ago resolved this potential conflict by either insisting on transparency/auditing the bills or even - and again P&G is a pioneer here - directly contracting with preferred suppliers and insisting that agencies use these players where applicable.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Putting this together, while we cannot exclude the possibility of some specific wrongdoing coming to light, we do not see this as a particular concern. The broader issue as we describe at the outset is that it is another factor - alongside the ANA review - that marginally undermines trust. We expect this news to be welcomed with some caution (the US peers were down 2%-3% yesterday after the announcement) but any more would be an overreaction in our view. We rate Publicis and WPP as Buys and Havas as Neutral.

undefined
BE11:30am

Oh, should mention since we're on WPP ......

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Sorrell was at some conference or other yesterday

BE11:30am

Said 2017 will be similar to 2016

BE11:31am

That'd suggest at least 3% organic growth, versus current consensus of 2.6%-2.8%, though it might be a mistake to take these things too literally.

11:02 am
BE11:03am

And it seems we might have a bork with the comment system.

BE11:32am

"Clearly there is some concern [among Facebook people] about the penetration Snapchat is getting"

BE11:33am

( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

11:32 am
BE11:33am

Oh, and he's also out to fix newspapers. So that's nice.

BE11:33am

"Traditional media owners themselves could put together an effective third force to counter the duopoly of Google and Facebook."

BE11:33am

We'll get right on it, sir.

11:33 am
undefined
BE11:33am

Otherwise, in media.

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 791.50, down 1.5 (-0.19%), High: 792.50, Low: 773.50, Volume: 1.44m
11:34 am
BE11:34am

Guess what! It's another educational publisher cutting guidance.

BE11:34am

Barnes & Noble Education this time.

BE11:35am

B&N says overall textbook sales down -3.3% in Q2, which is slightly better than Q1

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Though that's mostly because B&N is doing a price matching thing

BE11:36am

Pressure on enrolments unabated.

BE11:36am

More importantly, same-store sales guidance cut from 0% to -2% to -2% to -3%.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Shares down 14% overnight.

BE11:37am

What does it mean for Pearson? Well .....

BE11:37am

B&N's Q3 runs until October whereas Pearson's runs to September

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Citi incoming.

BE11:38am

The direct link between Pearson and BNED is slightly more tenuous partly because of the radically different business models (retailer vs. publisher) although we suspect the market will choose to interpret the change in guidance at BNED as a slight negative.

BE11:38am

They also note that John Wiley reports later today, which is the more important data point for Pearson.

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Pearson has already reported 9M US higher ed declines in the low teens of which around one third (c. -4%) was attributed to weak end demand and the balance of which was driven by flow back of inventory. The question is whether the flow back of inventory has continued to abate across October. To the extent that John Wiley confirms that it has, this could actually be a mild positive catalyst for Pearson.

BE11:39am

Wiley due at midday-ish.

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Okay, what else?

BE11:41am

(@dorsetcontrarian: I tend to ignore 2017 previews, sorry.)

BE11:42am

(And if I can do the quote myself thing ......

11:42 am
BE11:42am

("The 2015 FTSE forecasts have bunched around a 7 per cent gain, as they do every year. Over the past 30 years the FTSE’s average gain has been 7 per cent. It might be argued that prediction season demonstrates little other than the City’s faith in mean reversion.")

BE11:42am

( https://www.ft.com...-9f52-00144feabdc0 )

BE11:43am

Right, otherwise ......

11:43 am
Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,204, up 182 (+6.02%), High: 3,213, Low: 3,113, Volume: 2.82m
BE11:45am

... Which we can pin either on the CMD or on a Credit Suisse push in its 2017 mining review.

BE11:45am

Starting with the former, here's Caz.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

Rio Tinto’s London CMD reiterated key messages from the session in Sydney two weeks ago. The company intends to boost FCF by $5bn over five years via productivity initiatives in addition to the $2bn cost out target for 2016-17. At spot commodity prices we calculate 14% YE’16 gearing vs management’s 20-30% through the cycle guidance range, implying ~$4bn could theoretically be returned to shareholders, ~5.5% of the market cap. However, management also restated their comfort with gearing at or below the bottom of the 20-30% guidance range. We therefore see upside risk to the minimum FY'16 return of 110c/sh although moving to 20% gearing is unlikely. RIO trades on spot EV/EBITDAs 2017E of 3.4-3.2x for FY’17-18; we remain Overweight.

BE11:46am

And on the latter, here's CS.

BE11:46am

(@Monte: good to see you here, sir. Long time.)

11:46 am
BE11:47am

We maintain our positive view on the sector and make material
increases to our 2017/18 commodity price and earnings estimates. We see four positive drivers as we enter 2017: 1) we expect apparent demand trends to continue to recover following the aggressive destock through 2014-15; 2) consensus earnings remain too low and valuations supportive; 3) debt reduction could still be material (and under-priced) through 2017; and 4) rising yields and inflation expectations should remain supportive

BE11:48am

The first 17 of the 52 pages are a bit muddy. Here's the company specific stuff.

BE11:48am

RIO: Upgrade to Outperform... as surplus recedes
and dividends rise

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Action: Entering 2017 we upgrade Rio Tinto on 1) Vanishing iron ore surpluses as steel production rises and supply growth declines, 2) Attractive valuation, and 3) Balance sheet strength enabling additional shareholder returns. While we believe spot iron ore prices at c.$80/t are elevated and reflecting over-exuberant markets, we now forecast $65/t for 1Q-17, an average $55 for 2017 and $53 in 2018. Underlying EBITDA is revised up 46% in 2017E and up 51% in 2018E

BE11:49am

At the recent Capital Markets Day, Rio revised down capex and committed to a further $5bn of FCF in productivity improvements over 5 years. Value over volume is the new mantra, affirming that investment decisions need to consider the
potential impact of 1) price, 2) the cost base, and 3) sustaining/replacement capex – this fresh approach should be welcomed by long-term observers.

BE11:49am

Capital management potential: Not long after the dividend policy change we now find Rio having to consider capital management options as debt falls below target (2016E 19%, 2017E 13%, targeted range 20-30%). We now forecast a 150c dividend in Feb-2017 (above 110c guidance) and a significant boost in 2018 to $4.53/share or 100%+ payout and 10%+ yield (a base dividend of $2.53/shr + additional dividend/buyback $2.00). On our iron ore forecasts of c.$50-55 2017-18, the dividend payout can be 100% through 2020 and gearing remains below 20%, even with three on-going capital projects.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Otherwise .....

BE11:50am

We downgrade BHP to Neutral and retain our Neutral rating on Anglo. We see greater value in the diversified majors compared to the mid-caps. Our preferred mid-caps are NHY and BOL, while we downgrade KAZ and Aurubis (to Neutral) and FXPO (to Underperform). We maintain our Underperform ratings on ANTO, VED and KIO.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 1,233, up 38.5 (+3.22%), High: 1,241, Low: 1,215, Volume: 2.19m
11:50 am
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,343, up 31.5 (+2.40%), High: 1,343, Low: 1,313, Volume: 3.95m
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 404.90, up 5.9 (+1.48%), High: 416.00, Low: 397.00, Volume: 1.64m
BE11:51am

China tightening is a potential risk in 2017, but, as our steel team
have consistently written, apparent demand should continue to recover next year and, coupled with more disciplined supply side behavior (in China and from the majors), this should reduce the risks of returning to the deflationary spiral seen in 2014-15. Coal price volatility is likely to continue in 2017 and we expect prices to move lower. 2016 is likely to be a multi-year low for global mining capex; however, we are less concerned over a sharp increase in spend than some in the market.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Valuations: For the large caps, we are 15-30% ahead of consensus 2017 EBITDA with further upside risk at current spot prices. While the sector has outperformed this year, the stocks have recovered to only mid-2015 levels following a five-year bear market that saw the sector touch 30-year relative lows in early 2016. Assuming a normalization down in prices and margins in 2018, large cap EV/EBITDA of 5-6.5x still looks inexpensive compared to a long-term average range of 6-8x.

undefined
BE11:52am

Okay, I see the ROTR are talking Marxism. Inevitable, really.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

On this side of the page we'll make some vague attempt to stay on subject.

BE11:53am

There's Carillion .......

Carillion PLC (CLLN:LSE): Last: 245.40, down 10.7 (-4.18%), High: 265.00, Low: 240.80, Volume: 3.99m
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Which attracted some weird noise in recent days.

BE11:55am

No idea what the story was, is, or might be.

BE11:55am

And even that statement requires a Danger, because ....

11:55 am
BE11:55am

BE11:55am

That's Markit short to free float. Still at nearly 25%.

BE11:56am

(@Mouselet: mate, I've got a mortgage.)

11:56 am
BE11:56am

.... today we get a downbeat outlook.

BE11:57am

And figures that are less than brilliant.

BE11:57am

UBS to explain.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Increased operating profit but flattered by one-off Carillion is guiding for increased operating profit in 2016 (UBSE +1% to £237m) but this includes a one-off gain of £20m in support services. It is unclear whether profits excluding this would still be up. Net debt is expected to increase from last year's £540m (UBSE £550m), in part impacted by adverse translation of US$ private placement debt.

Order intake in H2 has been weaker, resulting in reduced revenue visibility for 2017 of 70% vs 84% at this point last year.

BE11:57am

Support services is expected to see revenue growth with margins up, but excluding a £20m one off profit, margins are expected to be flat (UBSE margins 6.2% vs 5.8% last year). PPP profits are expected to be down due to lower capital gains (UBSE £39m vs £49m). Middle East Construction is expected to see flat revenues with lower margins (UBSE 3.7% vs 4.2%) in part due to non-repetition of a one off gain last year of £14m.

Construction ex ME is expected to see margins within the 2.5-3.0% range (UBSE 3%). Overall we see the underlying trading performance as slightly below expectations.

BE11:57am

Weaker order intake since the EU referendum is in part explained by changes in UK Government Departments but means revenue visibility is now lower than last year. That said, Carillion is targeting revenue growth in support services and stability in
Construction ex ME, while the ambition is for Middle East to grow. We will seek more clarity on cash flow performance and quantum of net debt which appears to be deteriorating.

11:57 am
undefined
BE11:58am

@Chopper, on GKN, there's a Merrill upgrade around.

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 315.30, up 10.6 (+3.48%), High: 315.40, Low: 310.00, Volume: 3.61m
11:58 am
BE11:59am

.............. Though I don't have it to hand.

BE12:00pm

Otherwise on the sellside we have RBC pushing Aviva

BE12:01pm

We expect a re-emergence of growth in asset management, driven by the high-performing multi-asset fund AIMS, and in bulk annuities, as Aviva dials up its case size to take advantage of a structural growth market, to drive earnings expansion. We upgrade from Underperform to Outperform.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

We see a re-emergence of growth in asset management. Aviva’s multi-asset product AIMS should drive inflows for the whole group, due to strong performance since inception (+8.5%), and weak performance of peers notably the market leader GARS, and the strong reputation of the CEO, Euan Munro, with consultants. Our forecast net inflow at 13% of assets is market-leading. Our analysis indicates the net inflow into AIMS has been £800m in the 4th quarter to date.
…and bulk annuities. Aviva has always written a larger number of small bulk annuity deals – it wrote 34% of bulk deals in 2016H1 by number. We expect it will dial up the case size in 2017 to take advantage of one of the best structural growth opportunities in European insurance. By 2018E we expect annuities to account for 76% of Aviva’s UK new business profit.
Significant opportunity to cut costs. We see a significant cost cutting opportunity at Aviva due to a management team which we see as more focused than peers towards the shareholder. Aviva, which is the product of multiple M&A, always struggled to cut cost, in our view. The group consists of multiple discrete IT platforms and it has been simply too expensive to migrate these onto a single system. We believe the advancement of IT and the new digital focus which management has brought means this is about to change. 2017 will also be the year when the £350m Friends Life restructuring costs will fall away and the £225m pa cost synergies will be realised.
A strong and insensitive balance sheet. Aviva has historically suffered from a weak balance sheet and we believe the relative valuation (discussed below) still reflects this. However management cleverly addressed this issue through the acquisition on Friends Life and the resulting solvency is not only strong in the context of the UK insurance sector, with a coverage ratio of 174%, but also relatively insensitive to financial market movements.
Attractive valuation does not reflect the growth we expect. Aviva is one of the cheapest stocks on forward P/Es in the European insurance sector yet we expect solid 11%pa earnings growth (sector average 2%). The dividend yield is in line with the sector average yet we expect the growth to be the third highest at 8%pa as the cover is reduced (sector average 4%). This reflects a historic lack of growth which we expect is about to change. We increase earnings forecasts due to the growth we expect in asset management and bulk annuities.

BE12:03pm

What's the right valuation for the annuities an insurer writes? I'm not entirely sure I understand, given they look quite risky depending on where we are in the cycle.

undefined
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Midday!

BE12:04pm

That'll do for Wednesday. Thanks for joining.

BE12:05pm

Back tomorrow for the usual stuff. See you then.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

He also mentioned that WPP is spending $70m of its clients' money on ..................... Snapchat.
